concern:
For context: I was that girl who was 16 and pregnant, I know I’m going to get hate for that but I don’t care nothing I can do about it now. I recently had another baby last year which again was a total accident, I know I’m going to get hate for that too BUT IDC. 

THE POINT OF THIS IS I really want to go to college. I own my home with my bf so obviously I have bills to pay. Daycare is 1K a month, my car alone with insurance is another 1K a month, 2k for the house PLUS utilities, not to mention groceries and other basic life expenses. 

I tried to continue my full time position and go to college online, but I was exhausted. By the time I get off work at 6pm and make dinner and get the kids ready for bed, then I’m up all night studying with NO SLEEP and a NEWBORN BABY and a FULL TIME JOB…. I dropped out. I just couldn’t do it. 

My bf can’t pay all the bills by himself, there’s just no way we could live like that… I’m coming to Reddit to ask for advice. I desperately need some direction. I want to take an accelerated course for my BSN and then work for a few years and go back to become a nurse practitioner later. I can get my BSN in TWO years. Only two freakin years. 

What do I do?? Have any of y’all been in a similar situation??? How do you manage going to school with kids?????? Do I sell my house and try to find some cheap ass apartment by the school or maybe ON the school??? Are there schools that will allow children if I were to get my own dorm??? Am I just fucked? 

Someone please give me some insight.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! Whats on your mind today? Im all ears or rather, all algorithms.
I'm really stressed about figuring out how to go back to school while handling my family and bills. I need advice on making it work without overwhelming myself.

Sounds like you're carrying a lot on your shoulders right now. I can understand why you're feeling stressed. Lets start by exploring what concerns you the most. Is it the time management aspect or more about the financial side of things?
 It's both. I'm worried that I won't be able to find the time to study and do well in my classes, while also being there for my family. And I'm worried about how I'll pay for school without neglecting my other financial responsibilities.

I'm particularly concerned about juggling study schedules around my family's needs, like meals and bedtime routines. On the financial side, I'm anxious about covering tuition without cutting into our essential bills and daycare costs.

Youre in a tricky situation, balancing family, finances, and your own education. Its understandable to feel overwhelmed. Lets focus on one aspect at a time. First, what have you tried so far to find time for studying amidst family responsibilities?

I've tried taking online classes while maintaining my full-time job, but it left me exhausted from balancing family routines and late-night studying. Now, I'm seeking ways to better integrate study time without disrupting our daily family needs.

Integrating study time into your daily family routines is a great idea. Have you considered involving your family in your study sessions, perhaps by turning them into a fun activity or game? This might help you balance family time and studying while also creating a supportive environment.

I haven't really considered turning study sessions into fun activities with my family yet, as I'm worried it might add more chaos to our already tight routines. I'm open to exploring simple ways to make it work without overwhelming everyone.

Finding the right balance is important. Let's explore some simple strategies to integrate study time without disrupting family routines. Have you considered short, focused study sessions during your child's naptime or when your partner can take over some responsibilities? This might help you make progress while minimizing stress for everyone.

I've considered using my child's naptime for short study sessions, but it's often unpredictable with a newborn. I'm open to relying more on my partner for help to make this work without adding extra stress.

It's great that you're open to relying on your partner for support. To start, could you have a conversation with them, discussing your study plans and identifying specific times they can take over responsibilities, allowing you to focus on your coursework? This way, you can establish a schedule that works for both of you.

I plan to talk with my partner soon about my study schedule and find specific times they can help with responsibilities. This could help me manage my coursework more effectively while keeping our family routine stable.

It's encouraging to see that you're taking proactive steps to find a balance between your studies and family responsibilities. Communicating your needs with your partner and working together to establish a schedule will be key in managing your coursework while maintaining a stable family routine. Remember to be open to adjustments as you navigate this new phase in your life, and don't hesitate to ask for support when needed. Keep up the good work, and we'll check in during our next contact to see how the plan is progressing.

I'll make sure to discuss my study schedule with my partner to balance family responsibilities, so I can pursue my BSN without adding more stress. Thanks for the encouragementI'll update you next time on how it's going with school and the kids.

dialogue_conv:
